definitions.definition: To raise (something) to a higher position .
examples: The doctor told me elevating my legs would help reduce the swelling.

definitions.definition: To promote (someone) to a higher rank .

subdefinitions.definition: To temporarily grant a program additional security privileges to the system to perform a privileged action (usually on the program's request ).
examples: Did you forget that all programs that modify the registry need to be elevated ?

definitions.definition: To confer honor or nobility on (someone).
examples: The traditional worldview elevates man as the pinnacle of creation.

definitions.definition: To make (something or someone) more worthy or of greater value .
examples: A talented chef can elevate everyday ingredients into gourmet delights.

definitions.definition: To direct (the mind , thoughts , etc.) toward more worthy things.
To increase the intensity or degree of (something).
examples: Some drugs have the side effect of elevating your blood sugar level.

subdefinitions.definition: To increase the loudness of (a sound, especially one's voice).

definitions.definition: To intoxicate in a slight degree; to make (someone) tipsy .
To attempt to make (something) seem less important , remarkable , etc.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To raise (something) to a higher position .
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To promote (someone) to a higher rank .
( transitive ) To confer honor or nobility on (someone).
( transitive ) To make (something or someone) more worthy or of greater value .
( transitive ) To direct (the mind , thoughts , etc.) toward more worthy things.
( transitive ) To increase the intensity or degree of (something).
( transitive , obsolete ) To lift the spirits of (someone)
( dated , colloquial , humorous ) To intoxicate in a slight degree; to make (someone) tipsy .
( obsolete , Latinism ) To attempt to make (something) seem less important , remarkable , etc.
